context: Al Gore invented airplanes.

The B-24 was the most produced bomber of WW2. The B-17 stole all the glory but the B-24 was the workhorse that got it done. We gave many to Great Britain and many were converted to ASW aircraft, hunting down German U-Boats in the North Atlantic and Bay of Biscay. There is a restored one (a rare A model) at the local airport here in Addison, Texas that sells rides during events. I see it flying over my house a lot.

replies.context: Hopefully not with a full bomb load....took a ride on the B-17 "Sentimental Journey" out of Mesa, AZ few years back..was credited with downing two ME-109's and damaged a third.

Harder to fly, hydraulics were horrid, caught fire much easier as a result, harder to maintain and could not take the battle damage that the B-17 could. In spite of all of that, B-24 was good; B-17 was great..

The B24 could carry a heavier bomb load faster than a B17.  That's why Consolidated built so many.  In a belly landing with the gear up , the B24 would usually fracture behind the wing.  And, the B17 was a better looking airplane and would absorb incredible battle damage and still return to base.  However, both did their jobs.

Blame Fox for the late. It just showed on my string. As for you and your military buddies joking about death? That's your thing. not mine. As for me, 21 years Army Retired, Served in Korea, Germany, Viet Nam and Panama. And I believe that Rakkasans where Korean Airborne. Right?
Got the name in Japan but served unit served in every major operation since ww2

Ok, got it. I remembered because I was in Korea and at that time (61,62) you had to wear Class A Khakis in the summer. Some Airborne guys in the unit would wear jump boots, wings, and Glider patch on their overseas cap. The Koreans would always call them Rakkasans.
Those who do not know or study history are doomed to repeat it. Now go to your room and play with your woody.

context: Film it.  Post it.  Restrict it.  Leave it alone.
My dad flew a B-24 in WW2.  He said it was a hard workout with no hydraulics to assist with the flight surfaces... like a loooooong trip to the gym.

replies.context: There is a B-24 liberator that is still flying. It makes trips around the US every once in a while. I got a chance to fly/ride in it ($500 per person). Biggest thing I noticed was the personnel were a LOT smaller back then.

I saw it at the air show in Yuma a couple years ago. There was an old Zero, P51 and a few others. Not many left. As a kid in the west, the Forest Service used old B-17's as borade bombers for forest fires back then. Wish had paid more attention back then. Pretty grand to see them lumbering low over town on their way to a fire.
My grandfather flew a B-24 with the 15th AF in Italy. My father used to brag about how strong Granddad was. I think you hit on the reason.

I have researched, but not confirmed that it was the largest aircraft to not have any mechanical assistance (hydraulic/electric/whatever) for the flight controls...

I'd appreciate any confirmation/refutation.

RIP 1Lt "Dad"

context: Don't mess with it. RIP
My grandfather flew a Liberator over Italy. He was 19 years old in charge of 10 guys. Scary. I wish I had gotten to talk to him as an adult about his experiences.

replies.context: Yes we took it for granted back then. My grandmother worked on B-17's back in Chicago during WWII. She took turns with her friend to help assemble the twin machine guns in the turrets. The factories were going 24 hours per day and they worked 12 hours per day each. The big outing of the month was getting off to go to church on Sunday morning to see my great grandfather preach at the old Norwegian Lutheran Church.

My dad enlisted in 1942, shortly after his 18th birthday, and spent about 2 1/2 years in Europe. Before he died, we sat at the table and he gave me a German officer's pistol, holster, and magazine, along with the signed paperwork from SHAEF approving it as a "german war relic". I asked him where he got it, and all he would say was "France". Other than that he never spoke of his time there.

context: Article is garbage. That wreck has been known by the dive community for over 40 years. I dove on this wreck as part of a commercial charter in the early 1980s. I do believe the wreck may have been declared a war grave and diving is no longer allowed. BTW, the B-24 was empty when it crashed. It may have had an internal ferry fuel tank in the bomb bay. No munitions not even defensive machine guns

replies.context:
You sure this is the ONLY B-24 that went down in that area?
Just asking.

No but this one is in shallow water near the mouth of the bay.  In Castle harbor. Do you really think no one on an island where sport fishing and dive charters are industrial mainstays. In heavily trafficked waters, commercial boat captains know every  shallow snag, every wreck . Think the dive is in 50 to 70 feet. But it has been a very long time. The wreck appears not to be featured. May be a war grave and diving is usually forbidden in such wrecks.
Sorta like the "discovery of the New World"  which the folks living there knew it all the time.
